questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to OPD with a complaint of constipation. One week earlier, she developed a sore throat and a dry, nonproductive cough and was diagnosed with acute bronchitis. Drug treatment was started, and the cough gradually disappeared. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the constipation reported by the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Codeine Codeine is commonly used as an antitussive when a dry, nonproductive cough is disturbing the patient. Most opioids can cause constipation when used repeatedly, as in this case. MOA

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic with a dry cough for the past week. The cough was associated with a fever and chills for 2 days, but he has since been afebrile. He has no other symptoms. What opioid is most appropriate to treat this patient's cough?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dextromethorphan Dextromethorphan is an opioid used for cough suppression. It exhibits its cough suppressant properties by acting centrally on the cough centre in the medulla.

Highyeild:

Stages of dextromethorphan toxicity Stage 1 (1.5-2.5 mg/kg) Increased alertness Visual and auditory sensitization Generalized euphoria Restlessness Stage 2 (2.5-7.5 mg/kg) Exaggerated auditory and visual sensations followed by periods of deprivation Imbalance Hallucinations Increased energy and excitability Stage 3 (7.5-15 mg/kg) Visual and auditory disturbances Periods of semiconsciousness Delayed reaction and response time Impaired cognitive ability Mania and/or panic Partial disassociation Stage 4 (>15 mg/kg) Complete disassociation Hallucination/delusions Ataxia

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the casualty with a persistent cough and nasal congestion. He has been taking various prescription cough and cold medicines but did not know their names. A urine drug screen is positive for amphetamines. When confronted with this information, he vehemently denies amphetamine use. What is the best explanation?

options.label: A
options.text: He had a false positive because of codeine use

options.label: B
options.text: He had a false positive because of ephedrine use

options.label: C
options.text: He had a false positive because of marijuana use

options.label: D
options.text: He is lying about drug use

questions.correct_answer: B. He had a false positive because of ephedrine use
questions.explanation:
Solution:

He had a false positive because of ephedrine use Ephedrine is a vasoconstrictor used to treat nasal congestion and can cause a false-positive amphetamine drug test. Codeine, present in many cough medicines, would cause a positive drug test for opioids. This patient’s recent use of prescription cough and cold medicines could be expected to produce false positives in a urine drug screen in this manner.

Highyeild:

EPHEDRAS: EPHEDRINE Uses of Ephedrine Ephedrine hydrochloride has long been used to treat the acute attack of asthma. Its multiple activities, - numerous contraindications (coronary insufficiency, arterial hypertension, closed angle glaucoma, hyperthyroidism), - drug interactions (MAO inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants), -the required precautions (prostatic hypertrophy, cardiac insufficiency, diabetes), - potential adverse effects (tachycardia, headaches, sweating, agitation, insomnia, anxiety), as well as the fact that the effects wear out if the doses are repeated in close time proximity (tachyphylaxis) have led to the virtual (almost) abandon of this compound as a bronchodilator and analeptic. However, it remains available in some European countries like France for this indication, particularly in combinations (with theophylline, caffeine, and others ).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - This patient likely has ingested codeine, which is an opioid. Codeine would cause a positive urine opioid screen but not a positive amphetamine screen. Option: C - Abuse of one substance is often accompanied by abuse of another, but marijuana use would not cause a false positive for amphetamines. Ephedrine use is the best explanation for this patient’s positive amphetamine test. Option: D - This patient may indeed be lying about drug use, but his history of cold medicine use would raise suspicion for ephedrine ingestion. Ephedrine use is the best explanation for this patient’s positive amphetamine test

Extraedge:

Contraindications:- Ephedrine is contraindicated for patients with severe hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, organic heart disease, coronary artery disease, angina or other cardiac disease. Ephedrine is contraindicated in patients with closed-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: Rajesh 28-year-old man presents to the OPD for a follow-up of his asthma. He has had asthma since he was 8 years old and requires daily treatment for his symptoms. He often has nighttime awakenings with coughing spells. On physical exam, diffuse wheezing is heard bilaterally. He is willing to try anything to improve his symptoms. The physician decides to add Cromolyn to his regimen. What is the mechanism of action of cromolyn?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mast cell stabilizer Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer preventing the release of inflammatory mediators. It is dosed many times throughout the day and does not offer much benefit. For this reason, cromolyn is rarely used to treat asthma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with long-standing hypertension on enalapril presents to an OPD physician complaining of a chronic cough. The cough began when he started this medication. The most likely explanation for this finding is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradykinin stimulation Common side effects include dry cough, rash, fever, altered taste, hypotension (in hypovolemic states), and hyperkalemia. The dry cough, which occurs in about 10% of patients, is thought to be caused by increased levels of bradykinin in the pulmonary tree. It occurs more frequently in women and nonsmokers and with longer-acting ACE inhibitors.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B - Bradykinin stimulation causes chronic cough, not an inflammatory process. Option: C - Pulmonary embolism is highly unlikely in this patient. Option: D - This is not an infectious process. It is an inflammatory process mediated by bradykinin
